On Tue, Aug 5, 2008 at 3:12 AM, David D'Ambrosio <ddambro84@...> wrote:
> Hi Derek,
>
> I'm not really aware of much, if any benchmarking work that has been
> done in the field other than some of the papers mentioned in the other
> post. An outsider might think our ultimate goal is to create a French
> flag! I think it would be great to see such benchmarking of
> artificial embryogeny, as things seem to be about the same as when Ken
> wrote his paper: everyone is just trying stuff with their own system,
> without any regard to the other systems out there.

Right. It seems like there's a lack of rigor in determining the
representational power of these systems, and this is what I liked
about the way Ken addressed the issue in his 2003 paper. French flags
seem like a very rudimentary benchmark, possibly one that could be
included in a suite of benchmarks, but by itself seems to shed little
light about the representational power of a given system.

> Ken and I did try to do something like (although not as indepth as his
> paper suggests) with my 2007 HyperNEAT paper's results. I built a
> program that let me look at the Hypercube patterns and we were able to
> learn a lot about HyperNEAT by watching how the patterns changed over
> evolution, and were able to isolate modules that contributed to things
> like symmetry. We have a forthcoming journal publication about
> HyperNEAT in general that talks a bit about this.

Ah, nice. Please post a notice on this list when the article becomes available.

--Derek
